name: Vinpocetine
summary: Vinpocetine is a synthetic compound derived from the periwinkle plant, studied for its potential neuroprotective and cognitive-enhancing effects.
description: Vinpocetine is a semisynthetic derivative of the alkaloid vincamine, found in the periwinkle plant (Vinca minor). It has been used in some countries as a prescription medication for cognitive impairment, stroke recovery, and cerebrovascular disorders. Vinpocetine is thought to enhance cerebral blood flow, improve oxygen and glucose utilization in the brain, and exert neuroprotective effects via multiple mechanisms. In the United States, vinpocetine has been marketed as a dietary supplement, though regulatory status is under review and the FDA has issued warnings regarding its inclusion in supplements.

items: Cognitive impairment due to cerebrovascular insufficiency

sections.text: Inhibits phosphodiesterase type 1 (PDE1), leading to vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels; enhances oxygen and glucose utilization in the brain; has antioxidant and neuroprotective properties.

adult.oral: Typical dose: 5–10 mg three times daily
adult.intravenous: 20 mg/day for 10–14 days (outside US, followed by oral maintenance)

sections.text: Clinical effects on cognition may require several weeks of use; vasodilatory effects occur within hours of dosing.

other: May lower blood pressure; use with caution in hypotensive patients
Not recommended during pregnancy due to potential teratogenic effects
Regulatory status varies; some countries restrict use

sections.pregnancy: Contraindicated due to potential teratogenic effects
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in human milk; avoid use
sections.geriatrics: May be beneficial in age-related cognitive decline; monitor cardiovascular status

sections.text: No formal tapering required; however, gradual discontinuation may be considered in long-term users.

items: Evidence for cognitive enhancement in healthy individuals is limited and inconsistent
Often combined with other nootropics in dietary supplements
Regulatory status differs between dietary supplement and prescription drug depending on country
